speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: We'll hear argument in Hudson versus Michigan. Mr. Moran.

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: May I ask you whether there are statutes in various States that allow an officer to get a no-knock warrant? 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: And does Michigan have such a statute?

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: How common are those statutes?

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: Why would an officer, without such permission, want to make a no-knock entry while possessing a warrant --

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: -- a search warrant?

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: Why?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I don't know, I'd be worried -- you know, bust in somebody's door -- that the homeowner wouldn't shoot me.  Without announcing that I'm the police, he had every reason to believe he's under attack.  Isn't that a considerable 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 deterrent?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Exactly.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Right.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Yes.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I'm not sure I agree with a point that you make in your brief that civil 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 actions simply are of no use.  That might have been the case when we first adopted the exclusionary rule, but our docket is crowded with 1983 cases brought by prisoners, brought by convicted felons, and many of these cases are successful below.  What reason is there to believe that that wouldn't be an adequate deterrent?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Is that because the damages are slight or because there's a defense that is successful?  What has been the defense in these tort cases?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Of course, that same problem exists if the consequence is exclusion of evidence.  Courts are going to view it the same way. You're not going to avoid that problem by excluding evidence.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Well --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Well, I mean, your point is, it's very hard to tell whether they waited long enough, right?  And that's why they don't win a lot 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 of these cases.  But the same thing is going to be true if the consequence of not waiting long enough is the exclusion of the evidence.  The court is going to be very -- it's going to be very difficult to tell if they waited long enough, and, as you say, the court is likely to say, you know, "Let it go."

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Our two cases did not -- did not raise that issue.  The issue was not decided in those cases, was it?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Right.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: You don't -- you don't dispute the application of the inevitable- discovery principle here, do you?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Okay.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: And you don't dispute that the purpose of the knock-and-announce rule is not to allow the targets of the search to dispose of evidence, or anything of that sort.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Well, but it's a limited privacy right, of course.  These people have a warrant, right?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: So, how would you describe the privacy interest that the knock-and- announce rule is protecting?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: So, it doesn't go at all to the items that are the target of the warrant.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: And so, why should the remedy for the violation be to exclude those items?  The privacy that's protected isn't the cocaine, the weapons, the other items that were discovered.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: No, it's to protect privacy in the possessions and papers and effects. And these are possessions, papers, and effects.  It goes right to what the police are trying to seize, and you have an independent magistrate make a determination that there's probable cause to believe it, et cetera, et cetera.  The knock-and-announce rule is an entirely -- concerned with entirely different things.  And yet, you're enforcing it by excluding the papers, effects, and possessions.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Well, but just --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: -- just on the point of the causal relation that the Chief Justice was exploring, I mean, there is a causal relation in a but-for sense.  We know that. 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: I suppose the position of the Respondent is that the minute there's an entry after the knock violation -- the no-knock violation - - the minute there's an entry, that injury ceases, so that it's different from a warrantless rummaging- around through drawers and so forth.  I suppose that would be their argument.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Yes, but here it was a 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 warrant to enter the home, not to seize particular goods.  So, the entry of the home was not illegal. The entering of the home was perfectly okay.  What was illegal was not knocking and announcing in advance.  It seems to me that's quite a different -- quite a different issue, and the causality is quite different.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I understand that, but the essence of the violation was not the entering; whereas, in the cases, the old common law cases you're talking about, the essence of the violation was the entering.  Here, the entering was perfectly okay; it was the manner of it, the failure to give the advance notice, that made it bad.  And that, it seems to me, creates a different situation. 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Mr. Moran, would you clarify an answer you gave to Justice O'Connor at the outset of the argument?  You said there is no statutory right to get a no-knock warrant.  But did you say, as a matter of case law and practice, that can be done in Michigan?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: You mean, if you had a case where the reason you were arresting the guy is because he's shot through the door the last three times somebody knocked and announced, you still have to knock and announce, under Michigan law?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: But he couldn't get a warrant saying that.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: But that's -- that's actually what's disturbing me about this, because I thought the knock-and-announce rule was a rule that would allow a policeman to go in without knocking and announcing when he has reasonable grounds for thinking he might get shot if he didn't.  So, I -- as I read the briefs, I thought maybe that's not how it's being implemented, that the policemen are supposed to run the risk of being shot.  I didn't think that was the situation.  So, I'd appreciate your explaining that to me.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Would it be sufficient if the officer says, "One, this is a drug gang; two, they don't let people into the house whom they don't know; and, three, they have guns"?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Let me just be sure I understand the hypothetical case, where, three times before, there had been warrants served, and, each 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 time, the homeowner shot at the officer, the fourth time, they could go in without waiting.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: You think it would, okay.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: But you can't get a warrant that says he can do that.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: We've been down this 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 route before in other cases, like Wilson, but it's still a troublesome measure.  It's hard for me to believe that if a person has drugs in the pockets of his trousers or on the -- next to the chair where he's sitting, that he wouldn't immediately run and try to dispose them.  I just think that it's ordinary behavior.  And, if that's so, then it would follow that you never have to knock if you're looking for drugs that might be on the person.  Do you have any comment as to that?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: But --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: But if we say that a likelihood -- or that the -- or substantial probability that the evidence will be destroyed allows the no-knock, why won't that be true in every drug case, other than for what we said in Richards? 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: I mean, do people say, "Oh, they've got me now.  I won't get rid of the drugs"?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Well, when there's probable cause to enter, there's no presumption of innocence, is there, or am I wrong?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Do you have -- do you have any empirical basis for your statement that many warrants are executed and they don't find anything?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Do you have any basis for your statement that, in a large number, they don't find what they're -- anything that they're looking for?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: And you --

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: -- you don't dispute the fact that presumption of innocence -- the presumption 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 of innocence survives an indictment, doesn't it?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Yes.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: So probable cause is not enough to eliminate the presumption of innocence.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Yes.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: In --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Mr. Moran, these old common law cases you referred to, which held that a failure to knock and announce renders the entry unlawful, what was the consequence, in those cases?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Right.  And the evidence would -- if found, was not excluded, right?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: So, if we wanted to be faithful to those common law cases, we wouldn't exclude the evidence.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Well, then you shouldn't have cited the common law case. [Laughter.]

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: In the courts that have allowed this action to go forward, has the rationale been that there is no other effective deterrent to ignoring or violating the knock-and-announce rule?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Well, I suppose there are a lot of other violations of constitutional rights by the police that are very hard to get at, and that cannot be remedied.  And I suppose we could punish them by excluding all the evidence, as well.  We don't do so, simply because there's no causality.  We insist upon a causal connection between the two. It's not enough just to say the -- this is the only way to stop the police from making the violation.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: What about our opinion in Ramirez, where the manner of entry was such that there was damage to property?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: We didn't exclude the evidence there, did we?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Well, what had happened? Had they broken a window on the way in?  Is that --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Well, the entry remains lawful, despite the fact that the manner of the entry, which included the breaking of a window, was unlawful.  I think what the Court meant was not, as you're portraying it, that, objectively, the entry was lawful.  I think they were speaking: as a matter of law, despite the fact that the breaking of the window was wrong, the entry was lawful.  Just as your opponent is saying here: despite the fact that there was no knock-and-announce, the entry was lawful.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: But even if it was unlawful, it was not unconstitutional.

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: Mr. Moran, is it undisputed by you that the client would not have disposed of the drugs if the police had waited a few seconds?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, Mr. Moran.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Mr. Baughman.

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: Would you agree there is a knock-and-announce requirement --

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: -- even though there is a warrant?

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: And do you agree that that was violated here, that there wasn't really a knock-and-announce here?

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: All right.

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: Now, is exclusion of 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 evidence in these circumstances a deterrent, so that the police would be less likely to do that?

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: Yes.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Well, isn't it --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: -- the product, here?  I mean, if they had not -- if they had not entered, they would not have gotten their evidence.  Their entry, because it violated knock-and-announce, was unlawful.  So, it is a product, isn't it?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Well, an entry that conformed with knock-and-announce would have been lawful.  This entry didn't.  This entry was unreasonable.  So, I don't see how your argument fits the facts.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Well, but --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: -- I mean, how do you make that distinction?  I mean, it's like the -- you know, the Cheshire cat and a -- and the smile; you can't distinguish the two.  There was one entry, and that entry violated the knock-and-announce rule.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Well, how is that different from saying the entry is lawful, its only problem is, it was done without a warrant?  I mean, 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 you know, he's --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: -- inside the building; just, unfortunately, the means wasn't right.  No warrant.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: The means wasn't right. No knock-and-announce.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Well, but you might have probable cause, but just not have the -- have the warrant.  So, what is the difference between having probable cause to enter, but failing to get a warrant, and having a warrant, but failing to knock and announce?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Is it your view the entry was lawful or unlawful, in this case?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: No.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: So, in fact --

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: No --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: -- if they had a bazooka - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: -- that's not the question.  The actually -- actual entry was lawful, yes?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Oh, okay.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: And the same would be true if what they had was a bazooka, and blew the house up. [Laughter.]

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Yes, okay.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: So, basically, your argument rests on the fact that we can draw a distinction between entry and manner of entry.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: It's a --

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: It's a -- it's a strong argument, on the other side, that if we adopt your position, the officers would have no incentive, other than their own judgment about their personal safety, whether to comply with the knock-and-announce rule.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: What is the experience in Michigan?  The Michigan Supreme Court has had this rule for some time, that you don't exclude the evidence.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: How many successful 1983 actions have there been --

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: But you have not even one case that you can cite where a 1983 remedy was resorted to and was successful.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: But you're not aware of 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 any case --

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: -- where anyone has recovered --

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: On the no-knock warrant, do you agree that it's not possible to get one in Michigan?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Do they get to make -- do they get to make "inevitable" arguments on their side?  I mean, let's say, as what happened here, or as seemingly happened, the fellow is found near the chair with the drugs.  Can't they argue, "Well, if you had knocked and you had waited 10 seconds, he would have gotten up from the chair and gone somewhere else"?  And you wouldn't have been 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 -- able to argue, at trial, "He was sitting in the chair with the drugs."

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: There was something in the chair, right?  I mean, the --

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: -- the gun, or what

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Hmm.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: You wouldn't have been able to tell the jury, "I was standing next to the chair, because if I had -- I obviously would have gotten away from the chair, because I knew that's where the gun was." 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: So, you -- so, you think it's possible that the defendant could argue that the evidence should be excluded because, "Had he knocked and announced, I would have run to the toilet and flushed it down, rather than" --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: -- "answering the" --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Well, why not?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: That's causal.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: What do you say the purpose of knock-and-announce is?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: So, I take it your argument is that, except in cases in which the people inside the house are not dressed, or cases in which there is, in fact, a gun battle of some sort, that a knock-and-announce violation will, in fact, never be the cause of any damage at all.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: No, no, it -- no, but it'll never be the cause of any compensable damage at all.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Because I take it your argument is: what you can recover from requires causation.  And what I mean by "causation" is the causation of the harms which the rule is intended to avoid.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: And if the only harms that the rule is intended to avoid is the exposure of nakedness and violence, once inside, and there are cases without nakedness or without violence, then, in 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 those cases, there will never be a recovery.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: But, basically, your rule is, the police are entitled to take the chance.  If they -- if they get inside, and people have got their clothes on and there's no gun battle, no problem; nothing that the police are exposed to, either by an exclusionary rule or by a civil recovery.  And if they want to take that chance, if they want to take the chance that somebody will not be dressed or a gun will be pulled, basically that's their option.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Well, that's not true.  I mean, there are going to be situations, or at least possible, where evidence is going to be a -- causally connected to a violation of the knock-and- announce rule, right?  The situation -- the warrant is because these people were involved in a shootout with the -- you know, the Johnson gang; they knock the door down and somebody yells, "Look out, it's the Johnson gang."

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: And if they had knocked and announced, and "It's the police," they wouldn't have that statement that's incriminating. Now, you would agree that that statement would be excluded because of the violation, right?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: I can understand the requirement there be causal connection.  Are there cases in which courts have held that there was a knock-and-announce violation, and there is a general remedy of exclusion, unless -- except when there's a causal connection; but, in fact, the evidence was admitted because it was not causally connected to the entry?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: I mean, I can understand 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 the hypothetical, but it seems to me it's really a hypothetical.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Oh, I see your argument now.  I think your argument is, most of the fourth amendment rules are really designed to prevent warrantless entries.  But this one isn't.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: This one is designed to prevent damage to property --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: -- et cetera.  So, let's not have the exclusionary rule and rely on the damage remedy where that kind of thing actually occurs, which isn't often.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: And if we buy that principle, suppose we were to apply it in the Miranda area -- purpose of a Miranda warning is really to make certain he can have a lawyer, if he wants one, for example.  So, now we prove this guy wouldn't have asked for a lawyer anyway.  All the evidence comes in. I mean, it's an interesting principle.  I see the logic.  But it seems to me to have a lot of implications that this Court has never bought.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: I can't think of any other area, fifth or fourth, where we've bought it.  And I've tried to explain, in the question, why we haven't bought it.  Now, you go ahead. 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, Counsel. 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 Mr. Salmons.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: It depends, of course, on whether you -- what you're doing.  Now I see what you're doing.  You're applying a kind of Palsgraf causation analysis within the risk -- I think that's what you're doing -- to saying it's outside, it's not 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 a cause.  You're saying -- you don't say it's not a necessary condition of his being there.  It is.  You do say, "Well, the being-in-the-room-there is not within the risk, the reason for which we have a knock-and-announce rule."  But, of course, that's a matter of judgment.  I mean, you could say the purpose of the cause -- of the knock-and-announce rule is to keep people out of there without knocking and announcing.  And if that's the purpose of it, it's right within the risk, right cause.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: You just are looking at the harms that his being there in that room without announcing might bring about.  That doesn't mean that's why we don't have the rule.  We have the rule to keep him out of there without announcing.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: What was the --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: I'm sorry, I didn't mean to interrupt.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: I was going to say, What was -- what were the grounds upon which the warrant, in Segura, was obtained? 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: So, it didn't -- it didn't depend on the entry or anything gained as a result of the entry, right?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Right, but the --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: -- but the --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Right, but the warrant --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: -- the warrant -- the warrant itself didn't depend on anything they had gained as a result of the entry.  There was no --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: -- kind of causal --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: -- continuum there.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: So, you do --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Isn't --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Isn't that the difference, though, with this case?  Because, here, there is a causal continuum, at least, as Justice Breyer said, a but-for causal continuum.  They wouldn't have been in the apartment but for the entry.  And so, the authority of the warrant and the manner of executing the warrant are not divisible the way they were in Segura.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: But, in Segura, the court issuing the subsequent warrant says, "You can -- you can go in there and do this."  The court -- by the way, I -- maybe this makes it even easier -- did the court, in Segura, know that they were in the 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 apartment?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Okay.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: No, no --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: -- the difference is --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: All right, look, this -- you know, I'd appreciate your explaining this -- this seems to me what you're saying in your brief was the inevitable discovery.  The inevitable-discovery rule, in my -- the way -- the way I've thought of it, and I'd like you to correct me if I haven't thought of it correctly -- to use a kind of analogy, it's like a primitive tribe that beats a tom-tom every morning so the sun comes up.  Hey, the sun's going to come up anyway, and the bodies are going to be discovered anyway, in those cases.  And, in Segura, the warrant 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 is going to be issued anyway.  So, it isn't a question of whether it would have been issued if they had behaved properly, it's a question of what will really happen in the absence of the illegality.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Now, that's what I thought inevitable discovery here was, and, in the absence of these people entering the apartment illegally, they wouldn't have found a thing, because --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: -- there was nothing else in motion.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Now, which --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: -- case is contrary to what I said?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Segura?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: You have just said --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: -- that, in Segura, they would have gotten in, anyway, under a legal warrant that had nothing whatsoever to do with the illegal entry.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: The sun rose, anyway.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Right.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Exact --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: No.  Well --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: -- not "would have."  Did.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Then your --

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: -- position is that you never -- if you have a warrant, then you can seize what the warrant lists.  So, if you have a warrant, then there is never a reason that the police would have to knock and announce, because the warrant gives them independent authority to enter.  That seems to be what you're saying, that as long as you have a warrant, there -- the knock-and-announce does not have to be complied with.

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: Well --

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: -- but in this very case 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 -- you had an officer who said it was his regular policy

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: -- never to knock and announce --

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: -- to just go in.  So, if the rule you propose is adopted, then every police officer in America can follow the same policy.  Is there no policy of protecting the homeowner a little bit --

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: -- and the sanctity of the home --

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: -- from this immediate - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: -- entry?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: But what --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Wait a minute.  What is this incentive inherent in the circumstances?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Well, it doesn't seem to work.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: I mean, you've got -- this is a case in which the officer testifies, "It never works, I always go in."

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: When is it going --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: I mean, what reason do we have to believe that this incentive inherent in circumstances is ever going to work in the absence of an exclusionary rule?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Why don't they --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Why don't they have something to gain?  If they're right that there is evidence inside, they gain.  They're -- I mean, they're perfectly rational --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: -- in this.  They gain a greater chance of getting that evidence than if they let a few seconds elapse and the evidence can be flushed away.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: For --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: For which there is no record of any recovery in any court in the United States, isn't that correct?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Sure. 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank --

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, Counsel.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Mr. Moran, you have 4 minutes remaining.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I thought the Government's distinction was based on the fact that they were arrest cases.  I thought that's the distinction they were making.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Well --

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Well, isn't the -- isn't the reason it's consonant is because, in those cases, there is a -- the connection, in terms of the purposes of the rule that was violated and the evidence that was seized?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: But not the general privacy of the home, because you don't dispute that if he had waited an additional 4 seconds, he could have entered the home and executed the warrant. 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, Counsel. The case is submitted. [Whereupon, at 11:01 a.m., the case in the above-entitled matter was submitted.] 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400
